title: Iain Macwhirter  Scotland really is leading the way on climate change  but it won t be a walk in the park
story: Therersquos some doubt, according to the science journal Nature, about just how effective tree planting is as a means of combating global warming. Trees emit chemicals too, and darken the land, thus absorbing heat. But letrsquos not quibble. The Committee on Climate Changewhich inspired last weekrsquos landmark target, is in no doubt that mass reforestation ndash and wersquore talking billions of trees ndash will be one of the major methods of scrubbing CO from the atmosphere.Scottish Greens: How you can help fight climate changeScotland is well placed to deliver on this at least. Those barren hills and glens used to be under a dense covering of foliage. The forests were cleared for agriculture and charcoal in the south, and latterly for sheep and deer in the north. So mass forestation is only restoring the ecological default in Scotland.Nice to know, too, that Scotland, on paper at least, is leading the way on meeting climate change targets, having reduced emissions by a creditable % since . This is better than the UK as a whole, which is itself a world-leader in climate control. Scotlandrsquos abundant renewable energy is going to play a major role in transforming the UK economy.Transport is one of the main areas yet to be decarbonised, and every watt of that green energy is needed to make the switch from petrol and diesel in the next decade. Itrsquos long overdue. The internal combustion engine is th-century technology, horribly complex, unreliable and inefficient. Future generations will be astonished that we allowed our city streets to remain sewers of toxic chemicals.Mind you, the Scottish Government needs to put its foot on the environmental accelerator pedal. It is three years since I wrote a series of articles on electric cars after being allowed to drive some of them around Scotland. There were precious few charging points back then, and therersquos scarcely any more now. Yet, the electrication of transport should be a relatively simple exercise.Every petrol station should be a charging station, every supermarket car park, every school and hospital. Wherever cars congregate, in fact. The good news is that no-one who tries a modern electric car will want to drive anything , because they are faster, cheaper, safer and more reliable.Of course, manufacturing any car uses prodigious amounts of energy too, requires many costly materials and produces toxic waste. Electric cars arenrsquot a solution to climate change, but electrication of transport must be, especially micro-transportation. Every city in Europe seem to be turning to those electric scooters ndash except in the UK where they are illegal. Half of the bicycles sold in Germany now are electric. People are turning naturally to more energy-efficient transport so why not give them a push :Climate clock is ticking and now is time for politicians to fightThe CCC report was rather benign on flying. Yoursquoll be pleased to know that itrsquos not being phased out. This is probably because reducing aviation requires international agreement. However, cuts in air passenger duty seem dficult to justy. The Scottish Government wants APD cut by % to attract more business and tourists to Scotland. But Nicola Sturgeon is going to have to bite the environmental bullet here. The optics are wrong. It looks too much like a middle-class subsidy, even though many working-class people swear by Ryanair.Then therersquos the nuclear conundrum. Scotlandrsquos nuclear power stations account for % of electricity generation ndash a large proportion of our nominally clean energy. But they are old and unreliable and in need of replacement. However, nuclear power stations are regardedas a safety issue following Fukushima. They are also ruinously expensive and damage the environment by producing toxic waste which needs to be stored for thousands of years.The nuclear industry leapt upon last weekrsquos CCC report as a vindication of nuclear as part of the de-carbon equation. Big money is going into painting the atom green. But the prospect of the Scottish Government commissioning a new nuclear plant, given the explosive cost of Hinkley Point C, Englandrsquos first new nuclear power station in decades, seem remote. Renewable energy is much cheaper, joule for joule,it can be brought to grid fast enough. We are in a race against time to seeTorness and Hunterston can be made redundant before they fall apart.There are other issues too. Homes need to be insulated, gas boilers are going to have to go. Wersquore told to keep our home thermostats at  degrees, when most of us donrsquot have them. Itrsquos all expected to cost -% of GDP. But what was remarkable about last weekrsquos much-anticipated report was how doable it all appeared. By comparison with the apocalyptic forecasts of the climate Cassandras, like -year-old school striker Greta Thunberg, the CCC sounded like a walk in the environmental park. Nicola Sturgeon insists that cutting carbon will improve our health and wellbeing and the quality of le. Wersquoll all be happier, cleaner and probably working less in our new habitable planet.I hope shersquos right. There was an air of wishful thinking about last weekrsquos pronouncements. But therersquos nothing wrong with accentuating the positive. The problem with the more alarmist forecasts of Extinction Rebellion, who want net zero by , is that they induce not willingness to change, but a sense of futility and public apathy. If addressing climate change is going to involve banning travel, eating no meat, digging for vegan victory and plunging the economy into a biblical recession, as we close down whole sectors of industry, then people will not buy into it. The Yellow Vest movement was ignited by an environmental tax.Scottish Greens: How you can help fight climate changeIt may well be that the climate change targets are still too conservative. According to the UNrsquos International Panel on Climate Change, CO emissions need to be cut faster to prevent the planet warming by more than .C ndash the new tipping point. But the Scottish and UK governments have consistently outperformed their targets since they started making them seriously over a decade ago. They can do so again.Much of climate hygiene is self-evident. The public are morally signed up to it, and while abandoning their petrol and diesel cars may seem a grim prospect now, in practice it is likely to be a liberation. Most cars spend their lives sitting near a pavement losing value through depreciation. With proper public transport and urban alternatives, everyone wins.Vested interests are always a block on progress, but there is now a remarkable consensus, from the CBI to the GMB, BP to the NFU, the BMA to BMW. Addressing climate change need not take us back to a pre-industrial world of squalor, disease and hardship. The human race isnrsquot over yet.

title: the-15-best-places-in-scotland-to-have-a-picnic
story: . Loch Lubnaig, CallanderCallander, StirlingMeaning lsquocrookedrsquo in Gaelic, Loch Lubnaig is a far cry from the wide expanses of Loch Lomond or Loch Ness. But its narrow, weaving shape makes for a spectacular view from its banks, as the hills rise steeply ahead of you and peek around the corners of the horizon. There are plenty of flat, pebbly lochside beaches to plonk yourself down on, as well as dedicated picnic spots and the excellent Cabin Cafeacuteyou donrsquot want to bring your own food. And, along with admiring the scenery, you are also likely to see some hardy wild swimmers braving the water ndash no matter what time of year you visit.. Otterrsquos Pool, GallowayRaiderrsquos Road Forest Drive, Galloway Forest Park, Dumfries and GallowayOtterrsquos Pool almost looks made for picnics. The gently bubbling burn runs over rocks to pool in a charming forest clearing, with plenty of picnic tables dotted around to sit at and take in the surroundings. To get there, go halfway along the Raiderrsquos Road Forest Drive, a -mile woodland route that shows off some of the best wildle that Galloway has to offer.. Glenfinnan Viaduct Viewing Point, HighlandsGlenfinnan, Lochaber, HighlandsThe Glenfinnan Viaduct is recognisable the world over, thanks to the Harry Potter scene where the Hogwarts Express passes over its majestic arches. It makes a beautul spot for a picnic, with several dferent viewpoints that can be accessed from the visitor centre. ScotRail trains pass reasonably frequently on the route to Fort William, butyou want to see the iconic Jacobite steam train then you will have to time your picnic carefully as it only passes twice a day.. Conic Hill, BalmahaBalmaha, StirlingTherersquos nothing quite like the smug pleasure of tucking into a well-earned meal after exercise. And where better to do it than with a picnic at the top of Conic Hill  The summit of this steep, short peak offers some pretty spectacular views over Loch Lomond, and is the perfect place to just do nothing except soak in the scenery. The climb does require a bit of stamina, but it should be suitable for most ages and fitness levels.. Portencross, AyrshirePortencross, North AyrshireTroon and Prestwick might get most of the visitors, but those in the know would tell you that it is the clachan of Portencross that offers the best views in Ayrshire. Its proximity to Arran means it has an unrivalled outlook over the sea to the island ndash which looks particularly majestic as the sun is going down. You can head to one of the picnic tables dotted along the Portencross front, or to its small beach, but arguably the best place to base yourself is on the end of the pier.. Cambus OrsquoMay, AberdeenshireBallater, AberdeenshireThe erse, rich forest of Cambus OrsquoMay offers plenty of iety for visitors. You can picnic in the dense woodlandsyou want to get away from it all, in the open heather fieldsyou want a view of the Cairngorms, or at one of the riverside picnic benchesyou want to admire its suspension bridge. It was damaged in Storm Frank and is no longer safe to cross, but the -year-old bridge is still lovely to admire. Especially with a tasty picnic.. Botanic Gardens, Glasgow Great Western Road, GlasgowA bit of an institution among west-enders, the Botanic Gardens is an excellent place to unwind with a picnic on a sunny day. Any spot you choose is likely to be surrounded by beautul flowers, with the gardens hosting  specimens that come from more than  plant families. When you finish, make sure to have a wander around the striking Kibble Palace or the Kelvin riverside path to explore more of Glasgowrsquos greenery.. St Cyrus Beach, near MontroseMontrose, AngusThis three-mile-long beach, which is part of the St Cyrus Nature Reserve, has plenty of lovely spots for relaxing on a sunny day. You can get to it from the clf path or the visitor centre, where there is adjoining nature reserve to do some pre-picnic birdwatching. On the beach itself make sure to look out for seals, dolphins and killer whales, which have all been spotted offshore.. The Meadows, EdinburghOld Town, Edinburgh city centreIf you want a quiet, secluded picnic then the Meadows isnrsquot for you. But what it lacks in space it more than makes up for in people watching: with buskers, fitness fanatics, families and students all using the grassy fields for an escape from city le. Just be vigilant that you donrsquot have your food stolen by an over-friendly dog, or get hit by a stray frisbee from one of the many games that get played on the Meadows.. Fairy Pools, SkyeGlenbrittle, SkyeNot only was it named as Scotlandrsquos best picnic spot in , but Skyersquos Fairy Pools even made it on to the prestigious Lonely Planet list of the top  natural wonders of the world. If you want to see them for yourself, drive to the Forestry Commission car park of Glumagan Na Sithichean and then hike along the path for about  minutes until you reach the first of the waterfalls. There are plenty of dferent pools to explore ndash and have a picnic at ndash butyou are really brave you could even try swimming in them. Just donrsquot expect the water to be warmhellip. Crathes Castle, AberdeenshireCrathes, Banchory, AberdeenshireOpen every day .am-pmAdult pound, concession poundIf there is someone you are trying to impress, then a picnic at Crathes Castle should do the job. With its walled garden, perfectly manicured yew hedges and the backdrop of a th century castle, it makes for a pretty grand setting for sitting back and enjoying a sandwich. Be sure to leave time to explore the castle ndash and its beautul paintings ndash once you are finished.. Tentsmuir Forest, FeLeuchars, FeWith woodland, sand dunes and a beach, Tentsmuir has plenty of options for those looking to eat alfresco. There are dedicated picnic tables near the car park, but you can also follow one of the designated trails to find the perfect spot to set up camp. Look out for red squirrels, sea birds and dragonflies ndash and maybe even some seals basking on the beach.. Pollok Country Park, Glasgow Pollokshaws Road, GlasgowTo picnic alongside Highland cattle you might think that you have to travel to the countryside. But despite being right in the middle of Glasgowrsquos bustling south side, Pollok Park has its very own herd of Highland cows, along with plenty of open space and woodland. A great place to enjoy a picnic in peace.. Oldshoremore Beach, SutherlandKinlochbervie, SutherlandIf you want a picnic in peace, you canrsquot do much better than Oldshoremore beach. Along with its sister beach Phollain ndash the two are separated by a rocky isle known as Eilean na h-Aiteig ndash the south-facing bays of Oldshoremore can feel like your own private paradise. Anyone who canrsquot manage the steps down to the sand wonrsquot miss out too much, with the grass above the beach hosting more than  ieties of flowering plants.. Fearnoch Forest, near ObanTaynuilt, Argyll and ButeThis family-friendly forest has plenty of picnic tables to choose from, with ious trails through the woodland that you can explore to find your favourite spot. Some of the picnic tables even boast a view of Ben Cruachan, Argyllrsquos highest mountain, which peeks through the trees behind the forest.

title: what-does-it-feel-like-tocome-out-as-a-gay-dad
story: Lots of people are still homophobic today and I was concerned about the views of my family and friends and my work colleagues. Therersquos a culture and expectation to live a straight le and that was a factor in why I didnrsquot come out earlier, but in the end it was definitely my choice to come out. There was nothing making me do it, I didnrsquot feel pressured at all. It was something that I wanted to do and I realised that I had to do it. It wasnrsquot that I wanted to make a big statement about it, I just wanted to let people know.Of course I was worried that it was going to have a negative impact on my kids and thatrsquos probably one of the main reasons I didnrsquot come out when they were younger. There were dficult times, when I got orced from their mum, that was probably worse for them, but they were younger then. I donrsquot think being gay has changed my relationship with them, it hasnrsquot had any negative effect.Irsquom married now to Gareth. My kids had met him before, so they had been able to build a good relationship with him. I was in America at the time that we got engaged, so I phoned them from there to tell them that we were getting married. Both of my daughters were pleased for me and really happy about the whole thing. They just wanted to be sure I was doing the right thing by getting married, that I was making the right decision.Fatherrsquos Day is not the most wonderful time of the yearFor Fatherrsquos Day theyrsquove always bought me cards and little gts, that kind of thing, and they havenrsquot changed. Being gay hasnrsquot affected any of that. Irsquom lucky in that way. Irsquove got really amazing daughters that are quite easy-going about everything. Our bond has only become stronger as they have got older and we have all got a little wiser.Itrsquos a dficult decision to come out when you have children as what you do affects them. I would advise all people in this situation to be brave and realise, through my experience, that your fear of a bad reaction from those around you is never as bad as you think. I think itrsquos also important for your wellbeing and your relationships with others that you can be open about your sexuality. Thatrsquos why I think itrsquos important that people in the public eye come out, especially when these people are role models. Others will see that being gay is not something that is abnormal. I would like to see the day where there is no expectation to be straight and people wonrsquot have to come out.CHARLOTTE COHEN

title: actress-simone-lahbib-and-1980s-scenesters-relive-wild-youth-in-innes-reekie-photo-book
story: Only now, however, has the black and white picture of the Stirling-born actress made her a cover star. The cover in question is that of Nite Le During Wartime: Edinburgh and beyond -. This second of photographer and writer Innes Reekiersquos occasional series of pocket-sized photo-books is launched in an edition published by Jeremy Thomsrsquo Stereogram imprint at the capitalrsquos Stills photography gallery next week.Reekiersquos previous volume, Sometimes Pleasureheads Must Burn: The Birthday Party and beyond -, also published by Stereogram, focused on Nick Caversquos former band captured on a trip to Edinburgh. The follow-up, the Talking Heads referencing Nite Le During Wartime, immortalises a moment during roughly the same period when Edinburgh was brought to le by its own characters.ldquoI have such great memories of the old days in Edinburgh, says the now London-based Lahbib. ldquoI was there the other day, and me and a friend had a wander around, and reminisced about the flats wersquod shared and the places we went to, and all the second-hand shops. All the clothes Irsquom wearing in the pictures in the book are second-hand, partly because thatrsquos all we could afford, but partly because everything then was about being original, and being creative.Also featured in Nite Le During Wartime are images of dancer and choreographer Michael Clark during the Edinburgh International Festival run of his ballet, I Am Curious Orange, featuring The Fall. There are shots too of Edinburgh post-punk irregulars such as Boots for Dancing, Fini Tribe and So You Think Yoursquore a Cowboy, as well as poet Paul Reekie.ldquoIt was the height of Thatcherrsquos Britain, says Lahbib, ldquoand itrsquos really interesting that in the picture Irsquom standing next to the sign, because as Irsquove got older, saving the NHS is one of the things Irsquove become passionate about. So even though I probably wasnrsquot that politically aware at the time, itrsquos had an effect.Lahbib originally trained as a dancer, and spent four years at ballet school. By the time the image adorning the cover of Nite Le During Wartime was taken, she had made her onscreen debut in the title role of Cary Parkerrsquos piece of big-screen s Glasgow whimsy, The Girl in the Picture. Although the part was small, it gave her the taste for something more.Rather than capitalise on her film experience straight away, Lahbib decided to learn her craft, and studied drama at Queen Margaret College in Edinburgh. Early stage work included Wildcatrsquos production of Oh, What a Lovely War, with stints on Taggart before she moved to London. Once there, she was cast as a regular in long-running London TV soap, London Bridge. From there she moved into cop show Thief Takers before appearing alongside Forbes Masson and Stephen McCole in Skins creator Brian Elsleyrsquos mini-series, The Young Personrsquos Guide to Being a Rock Star.Lahbib moved into the mainstream by way of three series of Bad Girls, before joining Monarch of the Glen and appearing opposite Robson Green in Wire in the Blood. Lahbib also ran a performing school for young people. This led to her founding a childrenrsquosrsquo acting agency after one of her charges, Dylan McKiernan, was cast in Ken Loachrsquos film, I, Daniel Blake. Lahbibrsquos now thirteen-year-old daughter, Skye, meanwhile, has appeared in several seriesrsquo of Grantchester, playing her mumrsquos former co-star Robson Greenrsquos daughter. Lahbib also co-runs her own producing house, Contro Vento, with her husband, actor Raffaella Degruttola, with several films under their belt.Now back acting and producing full time, for Lahbib, Nite Le During Wartime is a step into a time when she and her generation were on the cusp of making it.ldquoGoing round all my old haunts and seeing Innesrsquo pictures has taken me back, she says. ldquoThere were all these people having fun, having adventures and doing these creative things that were about to take off. Innes was a part of that, but he was also taking all these pictures of everything that was going on. Clever him.Nite Le During Wartime: Edinburgh and beyond - by Innes Reekie is launched at Stills Centre for Photography, Edinburgh on June , .-pm. www.stills.org www.stereogramrecordings.bandcamp

title: fathers-day-is-not-the-most-wonderful-time-of-the-year
story: There may be a Fatherrsquos Day card on the doormat, but I donrsquot pull the envelope open with a sense of pleased anticipation. In fact, it feels more like getting my Higher results. That single, lonely, small, lsquoXrsquo after your daughterrsquos name, you assume, is really shorthand for, ldquoSorry, but you have underachieved as a father. This card owes more to prescribed social convention than the conveyance of heartfelt emotion.And I donrsquot expect more. I know I donrsquot have the sort of connection Atticus Finch had with Scout. I know wersquove never had a David and Harper Beckham kissy-kissy le together.But take this thought this Fatherrsquos Day feeling of failure isnrsquot about self-pity. Itrsquos about engendering shared experience, the disappointment felt by so many men ndash which has prompted the Families Need Fathers website to promote a Portuguese television advert.Read more:Bus passersrsquo highly active sex journeys come at a priceIn the ad, a child speaks in class ldquowith joy and knowledge of his day to day le with the parent he lives with. ldquoBut when it comes to talking about the parent whom he sees only every  days, words are harder and his knowledge is less. You notice discomfort in the room and you get the feeling of lives that are not lived entirely as they should.And thatrsquos a familiar scenario across the country where thousands of dads would love to able to reach out for the guitar next time their daughter visits and play the Paul Simon Father-Daughter song with that great chorus: ldquoIrsquom gonna watch you shine. Irsquom gonna watch you grow.rsquoBut you canrsquot because you didnrsquot. Not too often anyway. Instead you end up playing out a scene from the Neil Simon play, I Ought to Be In Pictures, whereby father and daughter central characters have lived almost separate lives.Now, the Hallmark card on the floor, or the Moonpig on the laptop, does little but heighten the sense of Imposter Syndrome.The words Irsquom reading in my head are: how can you expect to have a huge closeness when you havenrsquot earned it Yes, I can tell myself I made the -mile trip every chance I could, even though after her mother married, relations became so cold they made Lorraine and Esther seem like the Beverley Sisters.Read more: Harper Lee estate sues over Mockingbird Broadway versionI can remind myself of the many am set-offs, the trips to Blackpool, to Alton Towers, to the movies, eating KFC in the back row, the fun swims, the theatre trips.I can tell myself it must have meant something because we were both in tears at the end of the dayrsquos goodbyes. But none of that matters because what I also realise is Irsquove helped history repeat itself.Irsquove become part of the next generation of Scots men who thought wersquod learned from the disappointments of our own fathers and could compile the manual How To Build A Dad. Easy. Donrsquot be a drunk, invest time in the child, read them stories, play football with them, , never leave them alone outside a pub, tied up like a horse. Donrsquot gas their budgie in a fit of temper. And remember, physical contact can be pleasant when it doesnrsquot feature a whack on the bum.We all wanted to be dferent from our own fathers. Just because the Paw Broon generation did little more than puff on a pipe of self-containment, leaving bairns to their own devices, that would never stop us teaching them to ski, or play tennis or swim or how to whistle using a blade of grass between our thumbs.With all of this in mind, you think yoursquoll manage. When you hold that little girl for the first time, and she sucks on your pinkie, you realise, or hope you will be connected this closely for ever.You hope you will get to carry her to bed when shersquos fallen into a deeper sleep than a SleepingBeauty whorsquos swallowed three of her motherrsquos zolpidem. You hope yoursquoll be able to collect her from school.You simply assume yoursquoll have lots of chances to brush the tugs out of her hair in the morning, tease her into wearing warm, sensible clothes, .And you hope as she gets older shersquoll hoover up your Atticus-like advice. And you fully expect to see your daughter being collected by her date and feel, as comedian Jim Bishop did, ldquoit was like handing a Stradiius to a gorilla.But relationships donrsquot always work out. And disconnection results. It means big hugs are rare.Therersquos a Christmas time and a birthday period formality. I hope, that like Dorothy in The Wizard of Oz shersquoll come searching for a relationship with her father. But it doesnrsquot always happen.And I hope that some day Fatherrsquos Day will bridge rather than reveal the ide. And that it doesnrsquot take as long as it took for Jane and Henry Fonda to have their On Golden Pond moment. Or King Lear and Cordelia.When the father is bonkers mad and on his death bed itrsquos perhaps leaving it a little late.

title: flying-rats-or-flying-miracles-can-we-learn-to-love-pigeons-again
story: Understanding the relationship within the loft, the politics of it, is also something Donny has learned over the years. Over there in the corner, he says, is the alpha male, and that pigeon on the perch by the window is the stray whorsquos wondered in from somewhere . There are also some new birds, imported from Belgium that were sent over as chicks and have settled in well. Their claws clatter on the wood and they settle down again. Therersquos about  of them in all.The obvious question to ask Donny and his we Linda, whorsquos also a pigeon enthusiast, is: why do they love these birds so much  And therersquos a second obvious question: why do so many people hate pigeons with just as much passion  Another striking trend has been seen in recent years: a hobby, pigeon keeping, that was once one of the most popular in the country has declined precipitously. There were once a quarter of a million pigeon fanciers in Britain now there are some ,yoursquore lucky. Still a large number, but not a patch on what it was.: great places to enjoy Scotlands peerless wildleDonny and Linda Brooks have seen the change for themselves at their home in Wishaw. They point out of the loft across the line of houses on their street. There used to be a pigeon loft in virtually every garden, says Linda, but now therersquos just theirs. Donny says it was the same in Cumbusnethan, the nearby mining village where he grew up. ldquoA lot of the miners had pigeons, he says. ldquoIt was a working manrsquos sport but now there is an anti-pigeon mood. The phrase lsquoflying ratsrsquo stuck.So maybe itrsquos time to ditch that terrible phrase, flying rats, and replace it with something  that reflects the true, remarkable nature of pigeons. Linda says any animal can be a nuisancetheyrsquore in the ldquowrong place, but she sees the gentle joy of them every day. ldquoI miss them when theyrsquore not at the back door, she says, ldquobecause theyrsquore communicators. They talk to each other. You can hear them having their wee conversations.Another pigeon fancier who feels the same way is the writer Jon Day. Jon has just written a book about pigeons, Homing, which follows his efforts to establish a loft and breed racers, but he also explores the extraordinary and often mysterious qualities of the birds. They are miniature jump jets, he says, capable of accelerating from - miles per hour in under two seconds, but they are also just as intelligent as great apes, dolphins and elephants. But whatrsquos really fascinating is how they find their way home.ldquoItrsquos an enduring and controversial biological mystery, says Jon when I call him at his home in east London. ldquoMost of the consensus seems to be that itrsquos essentially a suite of dferent and fairly mysterious navigational senses that we may or may not possess.ldquoTherersquos certainly a lot of evidence that pigeons can detect the earthrsquos magnetic field, but they need to be able to smell in order to find their way home from an unfamiliar place and whatrsquos so amazing and beautul about that is not that theyrsquore smelling their way home ndash as we might with the smell of bacon through the house ndash itrsquos that the winds, when they blow from dferent directions, bring with them the sense of a base note and the pigeons can use the changing intensities of those base odours to work out where they have been taken in relation to their loft. Lots of the racers I meet have a sense of wonder and amazement at that fact ndash that this tiny, g creature can perform such impossible and mysterious actions.However, like Donny and Linda Brooks, Jon Day feels that a prejudice has built up against pigeons in recent years. Partly, he says, itrsquos because we have become much more house proud and people are less willing to tolerate their neighbours having pigeon lofts in their gardens. Keeping pigeons also requires a big commitment ndash itrsquos expensive but you do have to be at home quite a lot of the time to let them in and out of the loft. So, in many ways, keeping pigeons just isnrsquot compatible with modern le.Jon thinks therersquos something  going on as well ndash something more profound: some people love pigeons, and some people hate them because theyrsquore a bit like us. ldquoPigeons seem to mimic human behaviour, he says, ldquoso the place where they grow up generally becomes their home for the rest of their lives and they have this very human, it seems to me, relationship with a place. But theyrsquore also these kind of opportunistic, parasitic creatures that live in our spaces and environment and thatrsquos one of the reasons theyrsquore reviled. They remind us slightly of ourselves.Jon also thinks that what humans can see in pigeons helps explain why the popularity of racing pigeons has declined. In the early part of the th century, the birds were a vital form of communication and carrying messages from the battlefields made them heroes during the First and Second World War. However, Jon believes that, for the working class men that made up most of the pigeon racing community, their birds used to offer a kind of imaginative travelling that they couldnrsquot do in reality. Then air fares became more affordable and the pigeon fanciers could travel for themselves. They didnrsquot need their birds to do it for them and so slowly the lofts were shut up.: great places to enjoy Scotlands peerless wildleJon, and Donny and Linda Brooks, have all felt this sense of vicarious freedom in caring for their birds. Jon speaks about the joy of sitting in his garden in east London with a cup of tea and watching his birds flying overhead all the way through his book he also takes an imaginative flight with the birds, following their mysterious instincts as they race from Thurso in the far north to Leyton in the far south:  hours,  miles, their wings beating three times a second, their homing beacon taking them home.This freedom the birds have is important to every fancier, especially because there are some people who think keeping pigeons is cruel. In his book, Jon describes the methods some fanciers will use to win races ndash culling birds that havenrsquot performed well during the season, for instance. Donny Brooks also admits that there are some ruthless keepers out there. Not only that, the birds are at risk from predators in the air and on the ground and Linda Brooks tells me that, in any one year, they will lose a third to a half of their flock this way.When I ask him about it, Jon Day says that, in the end, he wasnrsquot prepared to use any of the tougher methods on his birds, but both he and Linda and Donny Brooks vehemently deny that pigeon keeping is cruel. ldquoWhen you open the loft, says Donny, ldquoitrsquos up to the bird whether it wants to go out or not and when it goes out,it wants to stay out, thatrsquos it. Yoursquore rearing a creature that wants to stay with you yoursquore its home and its keeper. In order to make a pigeon want to come home, you have to create a home that it wants to come back to.Jon agrees with this. ldquoI thought a lot about the ethics of the sport as I am a meat eater and a fisherman, he says. ldquoBut pigeons are free to do what they like when theyrsquore liberated so although I can see that people have objected to the sport, whatrsquos really being celebrated is a relationship that would otherwise die out and I donrsquot think itrsquos cruel. It has risks, as does horse racing and dog racing, and I suppose people who object to animal human interactions as being inherently exploitative might well have things to say about that. But every time you open the loft, the pigeons are free to leave and go away.Jon also believes that the men and women who love pigeon racing ndash mostly men, it has to be said ndash are reminding us not to take the species for granted. We might grumble about them now and complain about their mess and put up spikes to deter them or string that gets tangled round their feet, but shouldnrsquot we stop this stupid and cruel behaviour  Pigeons might not always be here.ldquoIrsquom conscious of the fact that these things look as though they are constants but that might not be true and we should step back, says Jon. ldquoPassenger pigeons were this hugely populous species of pigeon, mainly in north America. Up until the th century, there were flocks of up to a million but within a couple of decades they were wiped out by hunting. And they had a similar reputation in the public imagination as the feral pigeon.What Jon hopes is that, in time, we can rehabilitate the reputation of all pigeons and see them as their admirers do. As a survivor, like humans. As an almost perfect example of natural design. As a remarkable little jump jet that can hit  miles per hour in two seconds.ldquoIrsquom quite struck by the ferocity of anti-pigeon sentiment, among not just urban dwellers, says Jon, ldquobut often among people who love birds who see them as a devastating mono-culture who come and dominate. Jon believes, though, that there are ways we can learn to live together better and cites experiments in some European cities where large lofts have been built to encourage the pigeons to nest where they will not be a nuisance.ldquoOne of the reasons feral pigeons have been so successful in an urban context, he says, ldquois the fact they see our homes as their homes. Sowersquore going to build cities, we need to acknowledge that other creatures will live alongside us.Jon also points out that, while pigeon racing may be in decline in Britain, in other parts of the world itrsquos thriving: Morocco for instance and China, where earlier this year a buyer paid poundmillion for a prized pigeon. As for the chances of a revival here, Jon is not so sure.ldquoPeople donrsquot have the time or inclination to care for birds in their gardens, he says. ldquoYou have to be there and fly them twice a day, you have to train them and keep an eye on their health. And itrsquos not the most exciting spectator sport it has to be said ndash yoursquore not there at the start you just wait and eventually the pigeons turn up or not.However, one of the greatest joys of keeping pigeons for Jon is taking the imaginative journey, and he urges the rest of us to do the same. Play a game, he says, the next time you see a group of pigeons. Imagine where they may have been or where they may be going. Also, take a look at their legs to seeyou can spot a ring that singles them out as racers. Perhaps the bird is taking a rest before the homing instinct kicks in again. Perhaps hersquos decided to join a dferent flock and will never head home ndash it sometimes happens. But as you look at the pigeons, remember that an animal isnrsquot worthy of our attention and admiration just because itrsquos rare. There is beauty and wonder in the familiar too.Homing: On Pigeons, Dwellings and Why We Return by Jon Day is published by John Murray at pound..

title: mark-smith-nicola-sturgeon-could-you-please-stop-talking-about-scottish-values-there-is-no-such-thing
story: What, do you suppose, might those two words actually mean, because there wasnrsquot much indication in Ms Sturgeonrsquos speech. What she did say was that Brexit was a threat to Scotlandrsquos democracy and prosperity, which is where the word ldquovalues came in. ldquoThe deadlock at Westminster over Brexit, she said, ldquois going to lead to a world view even more at odds with Scotlandrsquos values and even more damaging to our future."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Nicola Sturgeon meets Jean-Claude Juncker and Michel Barnier in Brussels","description": "Nicola Sturgeon meets Jean-Claude Juncker and Michel Barnier in Brussels","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs VilFgCKH-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests VilFgCKH.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Now, you may think big speeches like this one donrsquot matter as much as they once did and I can understand that ndash besides, tweets donrsquot take as long to write. But a speech like Ms Sturgeonrsquos is a good opportunity to hear what a leader says theyrsquore thinking, as well as a chance to work out what theyrsquore actually doing. Ms Sturgeonrsquos speech was promoted in advance as a statement of support for EU membership and shared European values. Therersquos the V word again.However, there are several problems with the concept of values in politics ndash all of which were on display in Ms Sturgeonrsquos speech. The first is the definition: what on earth does ldquoScottish values mean  But more worrying is what happens when you promote one set of values over another. By definition,ldquoour values exist then so must ldquotheir values in other words, while purporting to promote similarity, the V word actually emphasises the dference. It isnrsquot a kind of glue, itrsquos a wedge.: Nicola Sturgeon calls Jeremy Hunt childish and pathetic after Brussels snubSo, did we get an indication from Ms Sturgeon about what she thinks ldquoScottish values means  Well, there was some talk about fairness and internationalism, but the First Minister might as well have said that Scotlandrsquos values were all kinds of everything: sailboats and fishermen, wishing wells and wedding bells. That, at least, would have been closer to the truth because when many people talk about Scottish values, what they really seem to be talking about is symbols: hills and glens and flags.The idea that Scottish people have ldquovalues also fails to understand how a country ndash or humanity for that matter ndash works. I was brought up in a family of four, in the same way, in the same country, but my siblings and I have dferent views on most issues ndash in other words, we have dferent ldquovalues and the same dferences occur outside of families. I share some ideas with some Scots, but I self-evidently donrsquot with others. My Scottishness, and your Scottishness, is irrelevant.If you donrsquot believe me, I challenge you to tell me what Scotlandrsquos values are. Perhaps itrsquos a sense that we should all be equal, but,so, in what way is believing in equality uniquely Scottish  And the truth is many Scots do not believe in equality ndash those opposed to gay marriage for example. Or perhaps you think our supposed openness to immigration is a Scottish value, but why, in that case, did so many Scots vote for Brexit  In fact, Brexit is not an English value just as pro-Europeanism is not a Scottish value and to say anything  is political vulgarity.And yet Ms Sturgeon appears to believe Scottish values do exist and therersquos a good reason for that. Nationalists, of the Brexit and Scottish iety, like to talk about values because they like to promote the idea of national identity. This can then be used to justy referendums or independence on the basis that ldquoour values are incompatible with the UK Governmentor the European Union . To do anything , and acknowledge similarities rather than dferences, undermines the case for separateness.This is exactly what Ms Sturgeon was up to in her speech and it happened again on Thursday when it was announced that Boris Johnson had topped the Tory leadership vote and the SNP reacted by publishing a mock ballot paper showing a choice between Mr Johnson and independence. No doubt, the First Minister would also say Mr Johnson is contrary to ldquoScotlandrsquos values when, in fact, Brexit is merely a policy and Mr Johnson a politician, just as independence and Ms Sturgeon are, and it can all be changed. Scotland and the UK donrsquot have values, we have governments with policies that will be superseded by governments with dferent policies.:UK Government to get first lsquoCabinet Roomrsquo in EdinburghAnd donrsquot we also have to ask where the concept of national values might take us next  A few years ago, Michael Govedecreed that ldquoBritish values should be taught in English schools, and who was to define those values do you think  Mr Gove, of course, because thatrsquos what happens with values ndash they are always defined by politicians, usually nationalistic ones, rather than parliament or the public. Values are an instrument of nationalism and of the state.Scottish nationalists would argue, of course, that they are dferent, that their values are civic rather than nationalistic, but itrsquos easy to imagine the future government of an independent Scotland insisting on Scottish values being taught in classrooms in the way Mr Gove did with British values. Indeed, I think some nationalists might insist on it to weed out unionists at an early age.Sadly, I can also imagine a Scottish government insisting on the teaching of national pride, another of the consequences of value politics. In her speech in Brussels, Ms Sturgeon spoke about pride in being a European, and perhaps some Scots would say pride in being Scottish should be one of our values too. But shouldnrsquot we be proud of the things we achieve rather than the things we are  To be proud of a fact you cannot change is fatuous. In fact, I think I can say that is one of my rules for le. It is one of my values.

title: bbc-question-time-viewers-praise-speech-from-francesca-martinez

title: unspun-the-political-diary
story: THE best question so far in the Tory leadership contest was posed to also-ran Mark Harper after he unwisely held an ldquoask me anything QA. Mirror hack Oliver Milne asked whorsquod win in a fight between a lion and a bear. Lion, said the MP, as it was the symbol of Britain. But where did Olly get his warped sense of humour  Unspun recalls him toiling as a Scottish Labour press officer. Not only was he there for the Jim Murphy apocalypse of , but he helped run Kezia Dugdalersquos leadership campaign. No wonder he tends towards the surreal.Best laid plans ...EXCITEMENT mounts ahead of an epic three-day debate on the Planning Bill. To tee it up, the government slipped through the dry-sounding ldquoBusiness motion  on Thursday. Once it was passed, Presiding Officer Ken Macintosh told MSPs: ldquoThat is agreed. Irsquoll just draw membersrsquo attention that we have provisionally put in a pm decision time on Tuesday and Wednesday next week. Cue groans from MSPs. ldquoYoursquove just voted for it, he snapped.Matter of principalSO, farewell then, Sir Paul Grice. Holyroodrsquos chief executive and clerk is leaving after  years with the institution he helped set up as a civil servant in the s. Hersquos off to be Principal of Queen Margaret University. What a wrench. But then education is a vocation. A comparison of recent accounts also reveals that, while Sir Paul currently trousers a meagre poundk in pay and pension, the head of QMU is on a cool quarter million. Such noble sacrice indeed.Cherry on top MODEST ldquoleadership figure Joanna Cherry QC has been making headlines after the leak of an email showing she sees herself a replacement for Nicola Sturgeon. The SNP MP is pals with Alex Salmond, so perhaps the great man has been inspiring her. In fact, our mole tells us Ms Cherry has even taken to occupying Mr Salmondrsquos former seat on the SNP benches in Westminster. Not exactly following in his footsteps, but you get the picture.Out of dateGOOD to see Scottish Labour is trumpeting its screeching conversion to a confirmatory vote on Brexit. The partyrsquos ruling executive passed the change last week, and also made it policy to campaign for Remain, even , er, Jeremy Corbyn was in power, and backed a new deal to Leave. Just the sort of thing that generates healthy online debates, you might think. Or it might,Scottish Labour had bothered to update its Facebook page since May , before the dismal European Election results that triggered the change of heart were declared.Nothing to sayDEVELOPERS handed over the keys to the UK Governments new hub in Edinburgh on Thursday, and bemused hacks were given a slightly surreal tour of the lovely, shiny, but very much empty office block beside Waverley Station. As they were guided aimlessly through the echoing spaces ndash which naturally include a swanky rooftop garden for civil servants ndash it became clear staff were running out of things to say. This reached its nadir on the ground level. ldquoThis is the entrance hall, journalists were told. ldquoItrsquos where people enter the building.Out of orderWHIFFY goings-on that evening as Scottish Secretary David Mundell held his summer drinks reception for the media in the basement of a pub on Edinburghrsquos Canongate. Mid-way through, a slightly stressed-looking member of the barrsquos staff came out with an empty bucket and announced the menrsquos toilets were out of order. ldquoWhat have you been doing, gentlemen  cried an anguished female voice from the back.

title: hugo-weaving-to-play-key-role-in-royal-lyceums-new-version-of-classic-sci-fi-solaris
story: The actor, known for his roles in the Lord of the Rings trilogy, when he portrayed Elrond, and The Matrix films, is to portray a pivotal character in the theatres new adaptation of Stanis#aw Lems Solaris.The sci-fi novel, first published in  and made into noted movies by Andrei Tarkovsky, in , and Steven Soderbergh, in , is to be brought to the stage by the Royal Lyceum Theatre, the Malthouse Theatre in Australia, and the Lyric Hammersmith Theatre in London.Weaving will play the role of Gibarian, who appears via video, rather than on stage, in the production as he communicates with the main character, Dr Kris Kelvin.Solaris tells the tale of scientists probing a huge sentient, oceanic planet and their subsequent contact with unsettlingly strange phenomena.Gibarian is the ill-fated doctor "whose love and fascination for the mysterious planet Solaris causes his mysterious demise just before Kelvin arrives on board the space station."The story is being adapted for the stage by David Greig, playwright and director of the Lyceum.The sci-fi tale will have a notable change from the novel and films, as Dr Kris Kelvin, the protagonist, will be a woman.In the celebrated  film by Tarkovsky, Kelvin was played by Donatas Banionis while in the  version, he was played by George Clooney.Kelvin will be performed by Australian actress Leeanna Walsman, during its Melbourne run, with casting for the UK version still to be confirmed.The rest of the cast includes Keegan Joyce as Ray, Jade Ogugua as Sartorius, and Fode Simbo as Snow.Solaris opens The Lyceumrsquos season in September.Greig said: ldquoWriting the adaptation for Solaris has been as fascinating as exploring a newly discovered planet."I had no idea Stanis#aw Lemrsquos book was so funny, so moving, and such a fascinating philosophical disquisition on the eternal human problem of our relationship with lsquothe otherrsquo ndash whether that other is a person, a planet, a lover or a monster."The premise is simple: there are three scientists on a space station orbiting a great planet, a psychologist arrives to check on their wellbeing, and strange things start to happen ndash is the planet communicating with them  Or are they imagining it  Is it a god  Or a demon  Or a child "He added: "Tarkovskyrsquos film is moving and atmospheric but discovering the novel was like uncovering a whole new layer ndash lively and witty and playful and a vision of the future that manages to be both entirely strange, yet as familiar as Hitchhikerrsquos Guide to the Galaxy or Red Dwarf."But this novel, and our imagining, is also ato the future as it was conceived in the sixties ndash science fiction on stage is so often about tin foil, sliding doors and empty space whereas this is about mahogany bookcases, smoking cigarettes and spools of tape."Irsquom delighted to be back in rehearsals with Malthouse Theatre again, following the stylishly sinister Picnic at Hanging Rock. Matthew Lutton is an incredible director ndash creative and cool ndash and itrsquos brilliant watching him bring the script to le with our international cast.Solaris will open as part of Malthouse Theatrersquos  season before arriving at The Lyceum to open the   season on  September.

title: former-wren-opens-up-new-chapter-as-a-writer
story: ldquoStill, I can look at a line of figures, Irsquove got it in my mind and it comes together. Itrsquos just bang on, Mrs Corbett Lamb said.She developed her arithmetical speed while serving as a cipher officer for the Womenrsquos Royal Naval Service, or, as they are affectionately known, the Wrens.Aged just  she signed up for the service in  at the outbreak of the Second World War.Now,  years later, she has written a book about her le during the war, in which she travelled across the world from a remote port town in the Highlands all the way to the Middle East.Mrs Corbett Lamb, who eventually settled in Scotland and now lives just outside Glasgow, recorded her wartime memories back in the s but her family decided to turn them into a book as a gt.With help from her son to fill in the missing details from her original notes and her granddaughters to digitise and edit them, The Making of Me was born.After printing a small batch of copies, which quickly sold out, her family said they will be printing more, perhaps even with a bigger publisher.ldquoI had no idea anybody  would be reading it but Irsquom awfully glad they do, Mrs Corbett Lamb said.Her father had served in the Army during the First World War as a cavalryman, and a painting of him atop his warhorse had hung proudly above the family mantle piece, so when the Second World War began she immediately knew she wanted to serve in the forces.She signed up to the Wrens and was stationed across the UK in busy port cities, such as Plymouth and Liverpool.As a cipher officer, her job was to decode messages coming in from allied ships who were fighting German U-Boats, such as those in the Battle of the Atlantic.ldquoNot all officers went to Bletchley Park, Bletchley was with machines, letters, the Enigma.ldquoBut the ciphers, they were little groups of four figures so you didnrsquot see any wording at all and you converted the figures into messages, Mrs Corbett Lamb explained.After her coastal city stints she headed back to London for further training.Aged  she became a qualied officer and when asked where she would like to be placed she hoped for another big city office.But to her surprise, she was ordered to report to Invergordon, a small port town north of Inverness.Though, she said she ldquonever had a better deal as this was where she met her sweetheart and future husband, sub lieutenant James ldquoJimmy Lamb.Jimmy met her from the train station, and when walking her back to the naval base he gave her no time to rest after her journey.ldquoHe said, lsquoWhat are you doing when you get up there rsquo I said Irsquoll be unpacking, and he said, lsquoWell, would you mindyou didnrsquot unpack except for your tennis things because wersquore missing a fourthrsquo.ldquoIrsquod just come off the train from London to Invergordon and this thoughtful gentleman said would you like to play tennis, but I quite fancied him, I expect, she laughed.She spent two years in the deep-water port before applying for an overseas posting.And, despite their blossoming romance, the pair didnrsquot do ldquothe done thing and decided not to become engaged beforeshe left.Mrs Corbett Lamb was posted to Egyptian port city of Alexandria with four other Wrens.She said: ldquoWell, obviously, we were excited. They were incredibly nice to us ndash the people of Alexandria welcomed us.While stationed in the Middle East she and her ldquole long friend and cipher partner, Helen, went on trips across the region visiting countries such as Palestine and Lebanon.They drank fresh orange juice, which was not available back home, and spent hours exploring the markets ndash where she bought a sheep-skin fur coat which never quite lost its ldquomusty smell.After rising to a senior rank in Alexandria, she and the other Wrens were ordered to head to Greece aboard one of the first allied ships to witness the Germans being pushed out of Athens.ldquoWe actually saw some of them chased off, the Greeks were so thrilled. They were on the map, we could see where they were and they were being pushed away, she said.Although the Wrens were mostly accepted by their fellow sailors, Mrs Corbett Lamb said they did encounter some hostility.During one nightsht aboard the HMS Ajax, she and Helen could hear a disgruntled sailor complaining about them from outside the cipher room. ldquoHe said, lsquoIt says in the Kingrsquos regulations that women are not allowed to do thisrsquo.ldquoWe winked at each other, my friend opened the door and she said, lsquoAny chance of a cup of tea rsquo He got the shock of his le, she said.At the beginning of her service Mrs Corbett Lamb and her fellow new Wrens fashioned their own unorms,as there were no public funds to provide them.ldquoWe were just girls doing a war job and we were determined to look like sailors, she said.By , she ed home from the Middle East with suitcases full of handmade shoes for every member of her family, a musty sheepskin coat,  eggs and a full Navy commissioned unorm.She eventually settled down withJimmy Lamb, going on to have one son, three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.ldquoIrsquom determined and itrsquos never worn off, she said.ldquoI guess thatrsquos why I was such a good Wren.ldquoYou never stop being a Wren ndash you never stop being in the Navy.

title: rise-in-number-of-people-with-second-homes-buy-to-let-and-overseas-properties
story: Research by the Resolution Foundation indicated rising additional property wealth in the past  years as a ldquoflipside of falling home ownership.The report, funded by the Nuffield Foundation, saidlatest data ndash for - ndash shows . million people reported additional property wealth, up % since .The value of additional property wealth has increased from around pound billion in  to pound billion over the same period, it was found.Additional property wealth is accumulated over time, and so is most common among older generations, said the report.Around one in six people born in the s have additional property wealth, the highest of any age group.The report said that buy-to-let property is now the most common form of property wealth, having grown by % since -.Around . million people have buy-to-let property wealth, compared to , people owning overseas property, which has not grown since , said the think tank.Policy analyst George Bangham said: ldquoMultiple property wealth has grown rapidly over the last two decades.ldquoWhile young people in particular are less likely to own their own home than previous generations, those that do own are more likely to have more than one property.ldquoThe sheer scale of additional property wealth is an important driver of rising wealth gaps across Britain.ldquoAs the huge stock of second homes, buy-to-let and overseas properties starts to be passed on to younger generations, Britain risks becoming a country where getting ahead in le depends as much on what you inherit, as what you earn.

title: increase-in-number-of-young-teachers-working-in-scottish-schools
story: Statistics published by the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Information Centreindicate there are , more young teachers in classrooms nowthan there was in  .The figures, based on teacher census analysis, also outlines that teachers younger than  make up around % of the total teachersrsquo workforce in Scotland .In , around % of teachers in the profession in Scotland were under the age of .SNP MSP Jenny Gilruth, a former teacher, said: ldquoThanks to Scottish Government investment we have thousands more new entry teachers in Scotland benefiting pupils theand breadth of the country.ldquoEducation is the SNPrsquos number one priority and by encouraging more young teachers into our classrooms wersquore building a committed workforce fit for the future.ldquoAs teacher numbers continue to rise across Scotland, itrsquos no surprise that our pupils are performing strongly across reading, writing and numeracy.ldquoDespite this great news, this SNP government wonrsquot rest on its laurels when it comes to education ndash we are determined to continue working hard to ensure each and every child in Scotland can reach their full potential.

title: methadone-overdose-figures-slammed-by-scottish-conservatives
story: A total of  people were admitted to hospital in - due to methadone overdoses.Heroin addicts are prescribed methadone on the NHS to help prevent them using the class A drug.Since records began in -, , people who have overdosed on methadone have been admitted to hospital.Annual figures have fluctuated in that time from a low of  to a high of , with no clear pattern emerging.Scottish Conservative health spokeswoman Annie Wells said the statistics indicate a new approach is needed to treat heroin addiction.She criticised plans for safer injections facilities in Glasgow as ldquounimaginative.Backers of this proposal, currently stymied by Home Office regulations, believe it will save lives by reducing accidental overdoses and cutting the cityrsquos growing Aids infection rate.The frustrating thing is that @scotgov @GCHSCP still do need #PermissionFromSajid to set up a drug consumption room that doesnrsquot look like this one. I want @sajidjavid to come to Glasgow and tell us why this is better than a safe, clean, treatment space with medical assistance. pic tZJVRLWDwmdash Alison ThewlissMay , Ms Wells said: ldquoMethadone is meant to help heroin addicts but now we learn it has hospitalised thousands in recent years.ldquoItrsquos a disgrace that the system is so utterly dependent on parking vulnerable addicts on this dangerous substance when what they need is actual help.ldquoWe need to remember that the vast majority of these people want to give up drugs altogether.She added: ldquoBut all they get is an SNP government which either feeds them methadone with no other alternative considered or allows them to inject the ruinous heroin for free at a state-run facility.ldquoThatrsquos unimaginative and will only worsen Scotlandrsquos already shocking drug problem.ldquoItrsquos time to see efforts going into changing the lives of heroin addicts for good, not making things worse for them.Her comments follow evidence from recovering addicts in Scotland to MPs that people can remain on heroin replacement methadone for  years ldquowalking around like zombies.A group of recovering addicts told Westminsterrsquos Scottish Affairs Committee instead of giving people methadone for y periods of time more cash should be spent on rehabilitation services to help them try to get clean.The committee is examining how to tackle rising drug deaths in Scotland, which hit its worst ever level of  in .A Scottish Government spokeswoman said: ldquoWe are committed to reducing stigma associated with the use of methadone and drug use more generally, and strongly encourage those in the public domain to be conscious of the impact that their criticism can have on those who benefit from such treatments.ldquoAll medicines are prescribed based on clinical need and discussed with patients within the context of their long-term recovery.ldquoPrescriptions should be reviewed regularly to achieve the best possible health outcomes and ongoing support should be provided to patients who are prescribed medicines.

title: women-make-up-more-than-half-of-public-board-members-for-first-time
story: It follows new legislation setting a target for % of non-executive members on public boards to be women by .The Gender Representation on Public BoardsAct came into force in March , and applies to health boards, enterprise agencies, the Scottish Police Authority, Scottish Fire and Rescue Service, colleges and universities.Of the  regulated ministerial appointments made to public boards,  were women, up from % at the end of .This encompasses  boards and women now make up half or more of the membership on  of them.Equalities Minister Christina McKelvie said more action will be taken to work towards all public boards having % women appointed.She said: ldquoWe are shattering the so-called glass ceiling.ldquoIt is encouraging to see these figures but it is important that we continue to encourage women to apply for these positions.ldquoThis progress has been achieved through the shared ambition and action of all of those involved and our Act will ensure that progress doesnrsquot slip back.She added: ldquoScotlandrsquos public bodies, colleges and universities are responsible for signicant expenditure and decisions on public services we all use.ldquoItrsquos therefore vital their boards reflect society and that womenrsquos voices are heard.ldquoThere is further to go to make sure each board has equal representation and that more of our boards are chaired by women but achieving % across all appointments is a signicant first step.The Scottish Government has launched a consultation on the regulations and guidance for the Act and Ms McKelvie encouraged people and organisations to respond by the August  deadline.

title: un-says-ebola-not-yet-a-global-emergency
story: The UN health agency convened its expert committee for the third time to assess the outbreak, which some experts say met the criteria to be designated an international emergency long ago.This outbreak, the second-deadliest in history, has killed more than , people since it was declared in August.The exportation of #Ebola cases from #DRC into #Uganda is a reminder that as long as this outbreak continues in DRC, there is a risk of spread to neighbouring countries, although the risk of spread to countries outside the region remains low.mdash World Health Organization June , At a press briefing following the meeting, Dr Preben Aavitsland, the acting chair of the committee, announced that the outbreak is ldquoa health emergency in the Democratic Republic of the Congo but that the situation does not yet meet the criteria for being declared a global one.For such a declaration, an outbreak must constitute a risk to other countries and require a coordinated response.The declaration typically triggers more funding and political attention.Dr Aavitsland said the committee was ldquodeeply disappointed that WHO and the affected countries have not received the funding needed to stop the outbreak and delivered a blunt message to donors: ldquoStep up.The outbreak, occurring close to the borders of Uganda, Rwanda and South Sudan, has been like no other.Mistrust has been high in a region that had never faced Ebola before and attacks by rebel groups have undermined aid efforts.On Thursday, WHOrsquos emergencies chief acknowledged the agency has been unable to track the origins of nearly half of new Ebola cases in DR Congo amid the challenges, suggesting it does not know where the virus is spreading.WHOrsquos expert committee has met twice previously to consider the situation in DR Congo.In April, the UN health agency said the outbreak was of ldquodeep concern but officials were ldquomoderately optimistic it could be contained within a ldquoforeseeable time.

title: catholic-church-in-scotland-urged-to-create-independent-safeguarding-watchdog
story: The Independent Review Groupwants the church to review the Scottish Catholic Safeguarding Service , saying a strengthened, independent and resourced service is a ldquocrucial step to promote transparency and restore credibility.The group, set up by the church in  to monitor its response to a major review of safeguarding and child protection, found a good start had been made on implementing the McLellan Commission recommendations but much more needs to be done.In addition to reviewing the safeguarding service, the IRG makes a series of further recommendations in its first report, including on support for abuse survivors.The group wants each diocese to have a clear policy statement on access and support for survivors, an independent person they can approach for advice, and to consider including survivor representation on safeguarding decision-making bodies.It also recommends further refining safeguarding audits, which should be independently scrutinised, and having a national training plan on the issue.The report states: ldquoThe Bishoprsquos Conference of Scotland should give detailed and urgent consideration to the creation of a strengthened, resourced and independent SCSS with appropriate professional support as a crucial step to promote transparency and restore credibility.It continues: ldquoMuch still needs to be done to ensure victims of abuse are seen, heard and supported by the church and the process of healing begins to take place.ldquoImprovement in policy and openness to learning from the audit process will start to sht culture.ldquoHowever, investment is required to develop a properly resourced professional safeguarding service.ldquoCommitment to create a dedicated, independent safeguarding service which supports the development needs of the eight dioceses drives consistency is empowered to independently investigate concerns or complaints and can act without bias in all its affairs is critical to rebuilding trust with congregations and the general public.Group chairwoman Baroness Helen Liddell said: ldquoThe problem of how the church is perceived is a universal one and signals the need for real and far-reaching change.ldquoThe vigour with which change is brought about, and is seen to be brought about, will determine whether credibility and trust can ever be restored.ldquoThere needs to be a change in culture, in capacity, in capability and that needs training, learning, reflection, the utmost transparency, and it needs leadership.ldquoWe have found a willingness to adopt that change, but true progress can only come about as a result of deep analysis of strengths and weaknesses.Bishop Joseph Toal, who oversees the SCSS, welcomed the report and said it would be given ldquoserious consideration.He added: ldquoSince setting up the Independent Review Group, we have taken steps to improve safeguarding practices in all eight dioceses in Scotland.These include publishing a manual of safeguarding procedures, revising the annual safeguarding audit carried out in all Catholic parishes and having independent audits of safeguarding practices in two dioceses, which will be extended to all.Bishop Toal said: ldquoWe are determined to apply what we learn, both from the steps we have already taken and from the IRGrsquos report, and to ensure that the highest standards of safeguarding practice are met throughout the Church in Scotland.
